text: The government should raise taxes on the wealthy to fund expanded social programmes (health, education, social grants).
Fiscal discipline and reducing public debt should be prioritised even if it limits new social spending.
The government should actively support small and medium businesses with tax breaks and deregulation to spur growth.
The state should introduce a universal basic income as a national policy.
Public investment in job-rich public works programmes is a suitable short-term method to reduce unemployment.
Healthcare should be universally publicly funded (basic services free at point of use).
Higher education should be free for all students, even if it requires higher taxes.
The state should provide strong subsidies for childcare to support working parents.
Local government services should be professionally staffed and audited regularly to reduce corruption and service failure.
Key public utilities (power, water, rail) should remain publicly owned and not be privatised.
Expropriation of land without market-rate compensation should be allowed to speed up land reform.
Smallholder farming and communal land rights should receive priority policy support over large commercial agribusiness.
Workers should have stronger rights to unionise and strike, with fewer restrictions.
Minimum wages should be increased significantly to reduce in-work poverty, even if some small businesses struggle.
Labour market flexibility (easier hiring and firing) will increase investment and should be encouraged.
Police should be given stronger powers and resources to tackle violent crime, even if it expands state authority.
Independent oversight institutions (judiciary, prosecution) should be protected even if it slows prosecutions of powerful officials.
Corruption prosecutions should be fast and aggressive even if they cause short-term instability in government.
Civil liberties such as freedom of expression and peaceful protest must be prioritised even if they complicate policing.
The state should actively promote LGBTQ+ anti-discrimination protections and inclusion policies.
Freedom of the press and protection of journalists should be strengthened, even if critical reporting targets the government.
South Africa should set legally binding national targets to cut greenhouse gas emissions and phase out coal power over time.
The state should prioritise investment in renewable energy and energy efficiency to reduce dependence on Eskom/coal.
Environmental protection laws should take priority over new mineral and coal developments.
South Africa should prioritise export-led growth through stronger trade links with international markets.
South Africa should prioritise building stronger strategic ties with other Global South countries over exclusive alignment with Western powers.
Trade policy should prioritise protecting local industries through tariffs and local content rules.
Public investment should prioritise mass public transport (rail and bus rapid transit) over new highways.
Affordable public housing projects should be prioritised over incentives for private housing developers.
Urban planning should prioritise green public spaces, walkability and mixed-use development over car-centric sprawl.
South Africa should adopt strong digital privacy laws limiting corporate and state surveillance.
Government should regulate artificial intelligence to protect jobs and prevent biased automated decisions.
Science and research funding should be substantially increased to drive innovation and long-term growth.
Food security should be achieved through a national strategy supporting local production, agroecology and community gardens.
Animal welfare regulations should be strengthened, including banning intensive factory farming practices.
Youth unemployment requires a dedicated national youth service and guaranteed apprenticeship schemes.
Special measures are required to improve accessibility and services for people with disabilities across government departments.
The state should introduce targeted subsidies and incentives to accelerate township and rural economies.
Cultural policy should support the diversity of South African languages and arts through stable public funding.
Voters should weigh a party's track record on delivery and corruption more heavily than its ideological slogans.
